sub_topic: Determining the isomerism of a molecule
message_1: Identify and draw the isomers of C4H10O and explain the type of isomerism exhibited by each isomer.
message_2:
C4H10O has three isomers: two alcohols and one ether. Here are the isomers and the type of isomerism they exhibit:

1. n-Butanol (1-Butanol)
Structure: CH3-CH2-CH2-CH2-OH
Isomerism: Chain isomerism
Explanation: n-Butanol is a straight-chain alcohol with the hydroxyl group (-OH) attached to the terminal carbon atom. Chain isomerism occurs when the carbon skeleton of a molecule is rearranged, resulting in a different structure.

2. 2-Butanol (sec-Butanol)
Structure: CH3-CH2-CH(OH)-CH3
Isomerism: Position isomerism
Explanation: 2-Butanol is a branched-chain alcohol with the hydroxyl group (-OH) attached to the second carbon atom. Position isomerism occurs when a functional group is attached to a different carbon atom within the same carbon skeleton.

3. Diethyl ether (Ethoxyethane)
Structure: CH3-CH2-O-CH2-CH3
Isomerism: Functional group isomerism
Explanation: Diethyl ether is an ether with an oxygen atom connecting two ethyl groups. Functional group isomerism occurs when a molecule has the same molecular formula but different functional groups, in this case, an ether instead of an alcohol.

In summary, C4H10O has three isomers: n-butanol, 2-butanol, and diethyl ether. They exhibit chain, position, and functional group isomerism, respectively.
